transcripts.text: This is the Dollamore Daily, and I'm Jesse Dollamore.  So acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney went on Fox News Sunday the other day with Chris Wallace and said some things that just aren't getting the amount of attention that I think they deserve.  Several minutes into the interview, Wallace asked Mulvaney about Donald Trump's seeming contempt and disregard for Congress's authority as an oversight power.  asking for clarity on Donald Trump's stupid statement during his State of the Union address about investigations and legislation.  Here's a reminder of the moment from his speech.

An economic miracle is taking place in the United States, and the only thing that can stop it are foolish wars, politics, or ridiculous partisan investigations.  If there is going to be peace and legislation, there cannot be war and investigation.  It just doesn't work that way.

And Mick Mulvaney sat there, right across from Chris Wallace, ignoring evidence of the many, many attacks from Donald Trump directed at the many, many different independent investigations into the Trump Organization, the Trump Foundation, the Trump Presidential Campaign, the Trump Transition Team, the Trump Inaugural Committee, and of course, the Trump Administration.  Mick Mulvaney hopes you'll believe that despite Donald Trump's constant cries of witch hunt, that he actually respects the rule of law and the co-equal authority of oversight, which has been outlined in Article 1, Section 8 of the United States Constitution.  You conservatives out there remember the Constitution, right?  Anyway, watch Slicky Mick here.  try desperately to square all of Donald Trump's attacks with his agreeing with the concept of their oversight.

The president absolutely agrees with the concept that the Congress has the right to do oversight.  It's one of their constitutional jobs.  That's not his point.  He's not trying to discourage them from doing it.  What he's saying is, look, you have a choice.  We can either work together on legislation or we can spend all of our time with you doing these investigations.  But you can't do both.
Wait, wait, wait.  You can do both.  And wait a minute.  And presidents have done both plenty of times.  Right.
But don't.  It's not reasonable to expect the president to work with you on Monday on a big infrastructure bill and then on Tuesday have you punch him in the face over 15 different investigations.
You were in Congress for six years.

This is where it gets good because Chris Wallace is forced to remind this.  pencil neck paid liar about his own role in all of the insane and seemingly never ending supply of partisan investigations carried out by him and his Republican colleagues during the Obama administration.  Investigations, again, which led nowhere.

You were in Congress for six years.  Are you aware?  I mean, you were.  You were there of what the Republicans did to Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton on Benghazi, on Fast and Furious.  And they got some things done, despite the fact that these were aggressive, partisan investigations.

Well, we didn't get very much done.  In fact, listen, I would be the first to admit that when the Tea Party wave, of which I was one, got here in 2011, the last thing we were interested in is giving President Obama legislative successes.

Did you hear that?  He just said that he'll be the first to admit that when the Tea Party wave, of which he was one, got to Congress in 2011, the last thing they were interested in was giving President Obama legislative successes.  All that talk from Republicans for all those years about how stubborn, lazy, averse to compromise, and arrogant Obama was just dissolved right before your very eyes and ears.  Because Tea Party Deanbat Mick Mulvaney just admitted that he and his Republican pals never actually cared about passing laws.  All they cared about was stopping Barack Obama.  Mulvaney, who was there for six of Obama's eight years and his Republican obstructionist pals, spent all their time lying about their purpose and their motivations.  But now we're supposed to trust them that their intentions are good and pure and patriotically grounded.  No thanks, dipshit.  I don't believe you.  Nor should anyone who actually cares about this country.  If for no other reason than the fact that you lied your way into the office that you sit in, which is only now feet from the man who you so loyally serve, who grew his own political capital by promulgating racist birther conspiracy theories about the same president you just admitted you spent six years in Congress doing nothing but denying legislative wins to.  No, I don't believe you.  You and all of your counterparts.
